repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: `vim.deprecate()` can be relatively significantly slower than
  the deprecated function in "Nvim" plugin.
Solution: Optimize checks for "Nvim" plugin. This also results into not
  distinguishing "xxx-dev" and "xxx" versions when doing checks, which
  is essentially covered by the deprecation logic itself.

Resolve #28459.

------

With this rewrite I get the times from #28459: `{ 0.024827, 0.003797, 0.002024, 0.001774, 0.001703 }`.
For quicker reference:
    -  On current Nightly it is something like `{ 3.72243, 0.918169, 0.968143, 0.763256, 0.783424 }`.
    - On 0.9.5: `{ 0.002955, 0.000361, 0.000281, 0.000251, 0.00019 }`.

------

If these changes are too much, another approach might be to treat `vim.tbl_islist()` as a special case and use custom logic there instead of `vim.deprecate()`. Something along the lines of `if vim.fn.has('nvim-0.11') == 1 then ...`, etc.

comment_regular_data.body: This seems to break diffview.nvim for me (not sure if its on neovim or diffview). Related issue: https://github.com/sindrets/diffview.nvim/issues/488
Hmm, that already happens for `vim.notify()` as well.

> This seems to break diffview.nvim for me (not sure if its on neovim or diffview). Related issue: [sindrets/diffview.nvim#488](https://github.com/sindrets/diffview.nvim/issues/488)

*If* it is this PR that broke it, then it will be due to `vim/_editor.lua:0: E5560: Vimscript function must not be called in a lua loop callback` and this one introduced usage of `vim.fn.has()`.

My first instinct is to suggest plugins to conditionally move to `vim.islist()` right away in such cases.

Otherwise, reverting this change and **highly** optimizing `vim.version()` might be the route here. But I think reaching the 0.002 ms mark will be tough here.
We could mark `fn.has` as async-safe (just need an exception for `has("python")` unless the recently provider refactor made it safe as well)

> My first instinct is to suggest plugins to conditionally move to `vim.islist()` right away in such cases.
> 

This also happens (sometimes) with telescope/plenary

```
Error executing luv callback:
vim/_editor.lua:0: E5560: Vimscript function must not be called in a lua loop callback
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'has'
        vim/_editor.lua: in function 'deprecate'
        vim/shared.lua: in function 'tbl_flatten'
        ...cal/share/nvim/lazy/plenary.nvim/lua/plenary/scandir.lua:207: in function 'scan_dir_async'
        ...cal/share/nvim/lazy/plenary.nvim/lua/plenary/scandir.lua:616: in function 'ls_async'
        ...scope.nvim/lua/telescope/previewers/buffer_previewer.lua:148: in function 'handle_directory_preview'
        ...scope.nvim/lua/telescope/previewers/buffer_previewer.lua:272: in function <...scope.nvim/lua/telescope/previewers/buffer_previewer.lua:267>
        [C]: at 0x5f831c0601e2
        [C]: in function 'pcall'
        ...share/nvim/lazy/telescope.nvim/lua/telescope/pickers.lua:440: in function 'clear_extra_rows'
        ...share/nvim/lazy/telescope.nvim/lua/telescope/pickers.lua:1461: in function ''
        vim/_editor.lua: in function <vim/_editor.lua:0>
```

note that `vim.iter():flatten()` does not have the same behavior as `tbl_flatten`, so I'm not sure if _all_ plugins can conditionally move to it (e.g. `vim.iter({ "command!", "-bar", [4] = "A", [5] = "B" }):flatten():totable()` raises. Ref: #28448)

This has broken a lot of plugins for a lot of people, so I suggest reverting it if a fix can't be implemented quickly. It's unrealistic to expect multiple plugins to update immediately. As it stands, I can't use neovim at all unless I revert this.

@sid-6581 which change broke plugins exactly, and how?

`tbl_islist` only calls vim.deprecate(). That isn't going to be reverted. It has no effect (except a millisecond change in run-time) until 0.11 anyway.

> This has broken a lot of plugins for a lot of people, so I suggest reverting it if a fix can't be implemented quickly. It's unrealistic to expect multiple plugins to update immediately. As it stands, I can't use neovim at all unless I revert this.

Reverting this will make a lot of those plugins unusable on Nightly anyway, because of `vim.tbl_islist()` will be about 1000x times slower.

The only solution I see is [suggested by @bfredl](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28470#issuecomment-2074650012).

Mason is one that's broken with the `vim/_editor.lua:0: E5560: Vimscript function must not be called in a lua loop callback`, and some other plugins as well. I'm in the middle of trying to get back up and running, but that was the common error I saw.

Telescope/plenary is another one as mentioned above.
Sure, we can try that. Or we can hardcode something, as a hotfix, until we have time for a more robust fix.

@sid-6581 polite reminder: we make zero guarantees about HEAD -- you're welcome to use it, but shit _will_ break. We appreciate a heads-up about possible effects on plugins, but we _don't_ appreciate the tone of "fix it nao _or else_".
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28492 will fix the `E5560: Vimscript function must not be called in a lua loop callback` issue.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lua): refactor `vim.deprecate()` for performance in "Nvim" plugin
